title: Site Download Page Error
author: bcolflesh
body_snippet:
https://mremoteng.org/ -> Download link in top menu -> Console error:

downloads:1  Failed to load resource: the server responded with a status of 404

comments.snippet: Several links on the site page do not appear to function correctly or the site seems incomplete. It seems like maybe the site is in development?
comments.author: sirweazel

comments.snippet: It's been down for at least a couple of months. Any way we can get portable downloads in the meantime? I only see installers on the GitHub releases.
comments.author: penguinairlines

comments.snippet:
> It's been down for at least a couple of months. Any way we can get portable downloads in the meantime? I only see installers on the GitHub releases. 

The GitHub Releases of 1.78 are all exclusively portable releases. Just download, unzip and start the application. Just note that changes to the config won't be saved as of now.

comments.author: penguinairlines

comments.snippet:
> [...] but I don't see the version-controlled backups being stored with the executable, e.g. confCons.xml.datestamp.backup.

The reason for this is that currently all saving is disabled in version 1.77.3+ (including all 1.78 as of writing) due to the rewriting of how the connections are stored and handled within mRemoteNG (i.e. separating the credential from the connection configuration). This is what I meant with "_Just note changes to the config won't be saved as of now_.".

comments.snippet:
I agree, if there's an ongoing rewrite about how to manage the config file, I wouldn't put much effort into an overlapping task - only enough to understand the behavior of the current release.

Let me know if I can clarify anything about my experience in this area.
comments.author: penguinairlines

comments.snippet: Considering there are still new releases (but marked as pre-release) on github, maybe it would be prudent to update the downloads page to show relevant package options, mentioning which ones are portable (and/or pre-release), etc, so that this project looks actually trustable, plus giving a way for users to more easily find versions they can trust to download. Maybe?
